Why I do Hyperbaric (HBOT)

(Longevity ‚Ä¢ Cellular Repair ‚Ä¢ Mitochondrial Health ‚Ä¢ Brain Health)

Most people think of HBOT for wound healing or diving recovery, but the science goes far beyond that. I use hyperbaric oxygen therapy as a longevity protocol focused on cellular repair, mitochondrial optimization, and brain performance.

Inside the chamber, pressure increases up to 2.0 ATA, allowing red blood cells and plasma to carry up to 1,200% more oxygen. This surge enhances cellular energy, helps reduce inflammation, may activate stem cells, and supports deep tissue healing, all key mechanisms linked to anti-aging and metabolic health.

Why HBOT is part of my longevity protocol:

‚Ä¢ Brain Health & Cognitive Performance‚Ä®Oxygen may drive neurogenesis, improves focus and clarity, and supports long-term brain resilience.
‚Ä¢ Longevity & Biological Age Markers‚Ä®Research shows HBOT may lengthen telomeres and reduce senescent cell burden, two biomarkers of aging.
‚Ä¢ Recovery & Performance‚Ä®It accelerates muscle and tissue repair after training, travel, stress, or immune challenges, supporting faster recovery and higher output.
‚Ä¢ Circulation, Healing & Detoxification‚Ä®More oxygen = improved nutrient delivery, better circulation, and more efficient cellular detox.

I typically do 1.5‚Äì2.0 ATA for 60‚Äì90 minutes, several times per week depending on my training load, travel schedule, and cellular repair phase. I am also doing a body protocol of 40 sessions 1x per year at 2.0ATA and a brain protocol at 1.5ATA for 40 sessions per year, then maintenance in between those protocols. 

HBOT is a most powerful natural longevity tool, using only oxygen and pressure to enhance energy, healing, and cellular function at the deepest level.

This is such a hot topic in women‚Äôs health right now and I‚Äôve done both types of training standard consistent training and I did try down regulating training in the luteal phase. Here is what we KNOW - consistency in training for longevity and overall health is absolutely critical. Personally, I don‚Äôt deal with any PMS symptoms, so I don‚Äôt need or benefit from down regulating my training in the luteal phase. BUT if you do suffer from symptoms, it would make sense to listen to your body and down regulate your training. I personally operate off my DATA, so looking at HRV, recovery scores, and overall symptoms or lack thereof, for example, I was recently in my luteal phase and had a bunch of travel, and I was scheduled to VO2 max training, but because my recovery was low at that point I push pushed out the VO2 max training to three or four days later after I had adequate recovery. I didn‚Äôt skip the training (because if I miss half a month of training every month I won‚Äôt hit my longevity goals ) but instead, I just pushed it out until my personal recovery was better. So excited to have just published ‚ÄúThe Information Theory of Aging,‚Äù 8 years after I started, and 4 years after publishing it in Lifespan üìñ. 
üß¨ 
The ‚ÄúITOA‚Äù states that a cause of aging is a loss of epigenetic information that disrupts the ability of cells to read the right genes, causing them to lose their identity & malfunction.
üß¨ 
The theory stands on the shoulders of former @mit professor Claude Shannon (see my sketch for Lifespan), who formulated ‚ÄúThe Mathematical Theory of Communication‚Äù in 1948, which led to the digital world we now live in.
üß¨ 
Over time, tissues become old & dysfunctional, manifesting as diseases, ranging from diabetes to Alzheimer‚Äôs. Reprogramming cells back to a more youthful state is possible using a combination of three Yamanaka factors (called O, S & K) or small molecules.
üß¨ 
In some species, such as axylotls, fish and mice, epigenetic reprogramming regenerates old or damaged tissue. Humans have largely lost this ability.
üß¨ 
If ITOA is true, it may be possible to rejuvenate organs by resetting the epigenome to prevent or cure a variety of diseases, thereby extending healthy lifespan. Human trials to reverse blindness are in the planning stages.
üß¨ 
Proud of the hard work by coauthors @Y_Ryan_Lu @XiaoTianPhD. The idea for ITOA was first published in 2008 (Oberdoerffer et al, Cell), and presented in Lifespan, this unifying paper took 3 years to write and get through the review process.
üß¨

üß¨ Aging is one of the greatest risk factors for cognitive decline but what if we could slow down aging-and prevent dementia or other neurodegenerative diseases and change the course of brain aging. 

üß† In our lab, we grow mini human brains-called brain organoids-to explore how the brain ages and how we might rejuvenate it. We start with adult cells (like human skin cells) and reprogram them into stem cells. These stem cells can grow into brain tissues, forming tiny 3D models in a dish then advanced imaging can be used. 

üî¨By studying brain organoids, we can uncover new ways to protect neurons and promote lifelong brain health. The future of cognitive longevity may start in a Petri dish üß´

Meet Konrad Howitz, the legend you probably haven‚Äôt heard of. Konrad played a huge role in the aging field by discovering molecules that activate Sirtuins. This discovery was surprising because enzymes aren‚Äôt often activated, and has been controversial and contested over the years - yet stood the test of time
.
Konrad and I collaborated for over a decade to elucidate the Sirtuin activation mechanism and find that the molecule prevents a wide range of ailments in rodents by mimicking fasting/CR. We also coined the term Xenohormesis together, the concept that stressed plants are beneficial to us because we‚Äôve evolved to sense when our food supply is at risk. 

Three cheers for Konrad!

Your mouth isn‚Äôt just about fresh breath, it might hold the key to your heart health.

The community of microbes living in your mouth, your oral microbiome is more than just a dental concern. Researchers are discovering that when the balance of bacteria in your mouth shifts (what we call oral dysbiosis), it can trigger systemic inflammation, invade arterial walls and contribute to cardiovascular disease.

Here‚Äôs how it works:

‚Ä¢ Harmful oral bacteria and their by-products can enter the bloodstream through inflamed gums or bleeding pockets. That creates a low-level chronic inflammation which is a known driver of atherosclerosis (hardening of the arteries). 
‚Ä¢ Some oral bacteria have been found inside atherosclerotic plaques (the very blockages in arteries), pointing to a direct microbial infiltration. 

‚Ä¢ The mechanisms are multifold: endothelial (blood‚Äêvessel) dysfunction, platelet activation (clotting), immune cross-reactivity, and more all linking the mouth to the heart. 

‚Ä¢ In fact, recent studies show that people with lower diversity in their oral microbiome have higher risk of cardiovascular mortality. 

So yes your oral hygiene routine goes beyond a bright smile. It might just protect your heart too.

‚úÖ Takeaway for you: Brush, floss, clean below the gum line, see your dentist, and partner that with your whole-body longevity strategy. Because when we‚Äôre optimizing health at Longevity Place, the mouth is absolutely part of the equation.

#Longevity #health #oralmicrobiome

üéß Do AirPods give off radiation? Let‚Äôs unpack the facts.

üí° Wired headphones have no wireless signal and therefore emit essentially zero radiofrequency (RF) radiation.

Wireless earbuds (like AirPods) use Bluetooth, which emits non-ionizing RF radiation, the same type used in Wi-Fi and cell phones. These levels are very low (around 0.001‚Äì0.01 W), but the difference is proximity: they sit inside your ear canal, only millimeters from your brain and cranial nerves.

üìö Here‚Äôs what the science shows:

‚Ä¢ A 2023 study found that long-term daily Bluetooth headset use was correlated with a higher incidence of thyroid nodules, though it did not prove causation (PMCID: PMC11192738). 

‚Ä¢ A 2016 review in Electromagnetic Biology & Medicine reported that radiofrequency exposure can increase oxidative stress and DNA damage in cells, particularly with prolonged close exposure (Yakymenko et al., 2016).

‚Ä¢ The World Health Organization (WHO) classifies RF radiation as a ‚Äúpossible carcinogen‚Äù (Group 2B), meaning more research is needed, especially on long-term exposure close to the head.

Important to noteC AirPods are well within safety limits

‚öñÔ∏è So what‚Äôs the takeaway?

While radiation levels are low, placing a transmitter directly beside your brain for hours every day is something our biology hasn‚Äôt evolved for. From a longevity and neuroprotective standpoint, it‚Äôs wise to reduce constant, close contact.

We often think of injury and stress at the level of tissues or joints. A sprain hurts, it swells, you avoid pressure, you rest. That entire sequence is an evolutionary program designed to protect the system while it repairs.

Cells follow their own program too, and it is far more specific.

When a cell encounters stress, it does not improvise. It shifts into one of a limited set of responses shaped by evolution. Molecular inflammation rises. Cytokines increase. Protein folding becomes unstable and triggers the unfolded protein response. Innate immunity activates. Reactive oxygen species accumulate.

This is the cellular danger response, and it is the same whether the trigger is psychological, chemical, physical, or metabolic.

What drives it is not the stressor itself, but the metabolites inside the cell. B vitamins, minerals, toxins like mercury, antioxidant capacity, and micronutrient status all determine how strongly a cell reacts and how quickly it returns to balance.

Understanding health at this level changes the way we think about stress, repair, aging, and resilience.

Visceral fat is one of the most active and dangerous tissues in the body.

The good news: it‚Äôs also the most responsive to lifestyle changes.
Even modest improvements in sleep, stress regulation, nutrition, and exercise can dramatically reduce visceral fat and restore metabolic balance.

Protein builds tissue, supports immune function and helps preserve strength, but it works best when combined with resistance exercise, especially as age-related anabolic resistance sets in.

Are NAD+ boosters always beneficial? Emerging data says: not necessarily.

A recent study in Nature Magazine Medicine [Nat Med 30, 1791 (2024)] highlights how chronic or excessive use of NAD+ precursors such as niacin, NR, NMN, or high-dose IV NAD+ can result in the accumulation of toxic downstream metabolites, including 2PY and 4PY.

‚úÖ Use physiological doses, guided by estimated NAD+ turnover
 üîÅ Cycle strategically, avoiding continuous, supraphysiologic exposure
 üß¨ Assess methylation status and detox capacity prior to initiation
 üß™ Track inflammatory markers, NAD+ catabolites, and clinical response
 ‚ùå Avoid indiscriminate stacking of NR, NMN, Niacin, and NAD+ infusions

Thanks to insights from my dear colleague Elizabeth Yurth, MD, ABAARM, FAARM, FAARFM, I‚Äôve become increasingly interested in 1-Methylnicotinamide (1-MNA), a NAD+ metabolite with vasoprotective, anti-inflammatory, and potentially anticancer effects.
